39220942.review:
I remember playing the origional N when it was a Flash game back in 2004/2005. It was one of my favorite Flash games at the time. It was a smooth, simple, fun and quite challenging platformer, and still is. N+, which I've never played, appears to be a console and handheld version of N. 

Now we have N++, an improved version of N, but for modern consoles and PC, with a level editor built in. It contains an incredible amount of levels, and even (if I'm not mistaken) all classic levels from N, as well as 'Ultimate' levels. All in all we're talking thousands of levels. Tens of thousands if you include community levels.

N++ is a good game, but can be frustrating at times. Balance is a bit weird, in that some levels that are very easy to beat will be very difficult when it comes to getting all the gold in said level. However this is not unusual for gaming. 

Some levels you will have to play hundreds of times to not only beat it but get all the gold, if that is your thing. What may take you 10 seconds to beat may take you an hour just to get all the gold without dying.

Overall a decent title.

38997648.review:
N++ is probably the best platformer ever created. You have the beautiful and complex platformers, and then you have N++. This game is so unique in its own way. Everything you do is your doing: no RNG, no unfair deaths, nothing but glorious platforming that will last you hours and hours and hours. 

You are a ninja. Your goal is to exit the level by collecting gold and avoiding enemies, mines and other possible entities. The game's difficulty can range from really easy for causal players, to excruciatingly painfully difficult for those hardcore players. So no matter what your skill is, you can still enjoy this game. Just to warn you about beating everything: This game is HUGE! Over 4000 levels are currently in the game, pluss an infinite amount of user created levels, so there's pretty much no end to this game.

There's also a co-op mode and a race mode for up to 4 players. Unfortunately at this time, there is no online co-op which is my only disapointment.

Overall, I highly recommend this game.

38260763.review:
SOLO:
The perfect platformer. It has no fat on it. There are no flaws. The only flaw in this game is the flaw you have as a player, that prevents you from beating the next level. It is all based on whether or not you can perform. Every win is proof that you can win next time. Every failure is just the first step to winning. It has style, the level names are clever and punny, manipulating enemies is gratifying. There's too much packed into this game to summarize, and nothing that shouldn't be there is present. 10/10.

LEVEL EDITOR:
Easy and simple as making pumpkin pie during the holidays. Follow the instructions, and then if you want to, get creative. The recipies for your levels are waiting for you to discover them.

IRRELEVANT PERSONAL OPINION:
This game taught me a very important lesson about life, believe it or not. I was playing through the E-row on the N++ levels page, trying to beat them all to get to the secret levels. Every time I would start a new E-row episode, I would play through it and get to the final level absolutely furious. I could not beat the final level to these episodes. It was very frustrating at first. Many times I literally pulled my hair out. But, what I learned was this, since this game does not save your progress in episode, if you give up on the final level, you cannot continue where you left off. You have to play through the entire episode again. This taught me to finish strong, to see things through. If you give up at the end, your progress means nothing and it was all in vain. It's helping me complete my work and studies on time, to be honest.

Also, this game has a ton of nostalgia for me too, because I've been playing this game for about 8 years now, since the first flash version showed up on flash game websites. So that aspect of it is enjoyable too.

TL;DR:
This game is the best platformer you will ever play, it tops Super Meat Boy and the original Mario and Sonic games as well. Just play it and you'll see just how high the standard should be for this genre.

Don't look at my hours - I have played the original N and Nv2.0 for the past 8 years. Now for my review -

I think this game, in its entirety, is MUCH better in every aspect compared to the previous versions.  

From character customization to level design, everything has been perfected.  Everything looks amazing, and the music choice fits the game as well.  The color schemes add much more to the game than the dull face of the original.  The colors change with the themes, so your character looks very different based on the mood (and also I gotta put in that the headband looks sick lol).

The levels, at first seem easier, but get a bit harder over time.  I would say that the previous version focused more on pure skill and techinicality/precision of jumping, but this has more puzzle elements to it.  Co-op is much better as well, and now you are capable of adding 4 players instead of just 2.  

I've never played with the level design, but I've heard it is very good.

The biggest reason why I like this game is because it is so relaxing and fun and a great de-stresser.  Just mf buy it.

I have to admit that I've played the original flash game N way back when I went to school and loved it, but wasn't able enough to finish most of the game.
Even back then, it had some of the best level design I have ever seen in a platformer regardless of the minimal controls (jump, left, right, suicide).
Then some time later, N+ was released for the PSP and NDS, sadly locking me out as a sworn PC gamer.
Now recently, N++ came to my attention as it appeared on my Steam store page.
Even though I have high standards for a new N game released on PC, it didn't disappoint me in any way and impressed me by maintaining its original vector graphics look which I think was lost on the handheld N+ version.
The level design is fantastic (and includes most, if not all of the previous titles), the soundtrack just as good and it has timeless looking vector graphics with loads of unlockable colour schemes.
I would absolutely recommend this to any fan of platformer games, but would tell them to try the free original N first to see if they can handle the difficulty.

36836911.review:
N++ — платформер, простой в освоении, но сложный в нюансах.

Суть игры следующая: вы играете за ниндзя и пытаетесь найти выход с уровня. Для этого необходимо добраться до кнопки, открывающей выход, а затем до самого выхода.
На прохождение отведено некоторое время — если оно закончится, ниндзя погибает, а уровень начинается сначала. Отведённое время можно продлить: для этого нужно собирать золотые хреновины, звук подбирания которых вызывает моральное удовлетворение и нездоровое привыкание.
Опасности в игре представлены не только временем. На многочисленных уровнях вам встретятся разнообразные враги и ловушки. Любое их касание убивает персонажа. Сражаться с ними нельзя, можно только убегать, перепрыгивать и прятаться за стенами.
Опасней всего может оказаться скорость, которую способен развить ниндзя. Разбиться в лепёшку можно классически, упав с большой высоты; можно разогнаться по вертикальной шахте и убиться об потолок; об стену — только с помощью трамплинов.
Уровней в игре — выше крыши, и по мере прохождения открываются всё более сложные уровни, на которых встречаются новые препятствия и/или больше старых.
Умирать придётся много и часто. Для интереса в одном из пунктов главного меню можно посмотреть статистику смертей, суммарно и отдельно по каждому источнику погибели.
Управление достаточно простое — только бег и прыжок, но инерция персонажа добавляет сложности манёврам. Сменить направление движения в воздухе проблематично, но возможно при должной сноровке. Освоение инерции меняет стиль и скорость прохождения уровней, позволяя совершать более сложные и точные прыжки.
Для прохождения уровней в N пиксельная точность по сути не нужна, гораздо важнее время. Зачастую движущиеся враги создают какой-либо паттерн движения, что заставляет торопиться проскочить в недолговременное "окно", или гонят персонажа по уровню, не давая много времени на отдых.

Прохождение уровней открывает новые цветовые темы для уровней, для персонажа и для головной повязки. Темы уровней в основном кислотно-вырвиглазных цветов, за редкими исключениями. Для любителей старины: тема plus выставляет цвета "под старый N".

Помимо одиночной игры есть пара кооперативных режимов: прохождение и гонка. Они расчитаны на hot-seat, то бишь на игру с одного компа. Сетевой игры нет, поскольку (по словам разработчиков) малейший пинг ломает отзывчивость управления, из-за чего теряется вся прелесть игры — возможность двигаться быстро и точно.

Кроме встроенного набора уровней можно поиграть в уровни, созданные другими игроками. В игре есть встроенный редактор, позволяющий создать свой уровень без ограничений в сложности и навороченности. Созданный уровень можно тут же проверить, на ходу поправить неудачные места, и, если захочется, выложить в общий доступ.

Первая версия N вышла в виде флэш-игры в 2004 году, и с неё началась моя любовь к такого рода играм. В N++ полностью сохранён дух старой игры, а новые элементы только добавляют разнообразия в игровой процесс. Это отличная игра, одинаково подходящая и для начинающих, и для матёрых любителей платформеров. Без ограничения по возрасту.

36678585.review:
Despite the enormous glut of platformers out there, you’ll find few as essential to the genre as the N series. Now over twelve years old, N boiled down the platformer genre to its barest essentials and then cranked up the difficulty that could be offered through those mechanics. We’re two generations removed from the original Flash release, and N++ contains all the content, concepts, and challenge you would expect from an evolution of the series. Assuming you can hang with the precipitous difficulty curve, there’s an absurd amount to discover about the game even for fans of N and N+.

You’re a ninja, which is a pretty good plot hook in and of itself. There’s no story offered aside from you loving gold and you needing to escape… wherever the hell you are. This translates into single-screen levels with an exit door and a switch that opens said door. All you have to do is hit the switch and get out before time runs out, and collecting gold helps bump your timer back up. Complicating matters are a vast array of explosives, lasers, drones, clones, zappers, and other traps between you, the gold, and the exit. The further you get into the game the more you’ll need to cheat death as you sprint and wall-jump your way from one level to the next.

It’s a challenge platformer, one that prides itself on giving you simple, solid mechanics and pressing you to master them completely. You have no attacks or special moves, just a brisk run, a floaty jump, and the ability to cling to and leap from walls. Everything in your way kills you instantly with just a touch, even walls and ceilings if you get your momentum up high enough. The controls are impossibly tight so you have full command of your ninja in weaving through minefields and springing from narrow ledges, and they even hide a few clever mechanics like being able to reach high ascent speeds through quick wall jumps or getting extra air from leaping perpendicularly from inclines.

There’s always going to be a frustration factor with instant death platformers but N++ handles this aspect with an expert level of wisdom. Respawns are near-instant, and with levels being only one screen large there’s a general limit on how long they can be. However, levels are grouped together in sets of five that must be beaten in a single sitting. You can always quit a level if it’s too hard and come back to it later but sets must be started from the beginning, so if you’re stuck on the last of the five there’s a very real pressure on you to power through it. Late in the game this subtle goading is used to great effect in sets that have multiple problem levels, keeping you chipping away at the latter ones just because the former ones were such a pain.

The levels themselves are exquisite works of minimalist art, living squarely in that space of clean lines and smooth animations that REZ, Lumines, and EDGE occupy. Most have some resemblance or pattern or meaning in their structure, supported by clever titles always shown in the lower right corner. You’ll also unlock color schemes as you play, allowing you to change the simple grays to vibrant mixes of every hue imaginable. Some even introduce their own challenges by making certain traps blend together, but can certainly be avoided in favor of more practical, high-contrast palettes.

With such a simple gameplay concept it’s the traps that give this one life, and it’s also the traps that fans of N and N+ will be most concerned with. Most of the design is based around mines, explodey things that will kill you instantly. Levels often have these dotted along walls, laid in patches on floors, protruding from corners, and assembled into aesthetically-pleasing clusters all to threaten you with death if you flub a wall jump. N++ introduces a major new mechanic here with inactive mines that arm after touching them once. This allows for entirely new styles of levels where you have to choose your paths carefully lest you render them impossibly lethal for the return trip.

While mines will be your primary nemesis, there are plenty more ways to end your very swift and mobile life. Electrified drones and seekers will trace walls or home in on you to kill you with a touch. Turrets of all types, machine gun, laser, and the dreaded homing missile, will track you if you dare poke your head out of cover. Moving platforms, one-way floors, trap doors, and powerful springs can all help or hinder your progress depending on how they’re used. A few notable additions here include accelerators that boost your momentum when you pass them, used to launch you over gaps or crush you against walls. Then there are the clones, ominous swirls that form into copies of you that follow your moves exactly and kill you if they catch up to you. The new additions for this version in particular are used to set up some very clever and unique challenges, keeping the game fresh even for long-time veterans of the series.

Rounding out this solid offering is the fact that it is absurdly huge in scope. There are, and I’m not making this up, over 1500 single-player levels to complete. Sets of levels are arranged in a huge grid with the top row unlocked, and beating one of those sets unlocks the set below it which gives some much-needed flexibility in level selection. Then if you beat a set of five sets it becomes unlocked in Hardcore mode, where your retries are limited and tied to your timer. You’ve also got hundreds of Co-op and Race levels for local multiplayer, and then the vast oceans of user-created levels to choose from. All this makes N++ not just the definitive entry in the N series but one of the definitive challenge platformers in the genre. Near-flawless mechanics, clever level design, and massive amounts of content make it a must-have for any fan of platformers.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish]curation page[/url]!

36449273.review:
This games controls are the definition of easy to pick up, hard to master. You essentially move left and right, and jump, but theres really a lot more to it. The features of this game are overall not complicated, but very fun to play with. Visuals are pretty minimalistic, but attractive, and there are a lot of color schemes to choose from. Soundtrack is pretty good.

This also has a lot more replayability than you'd expect for a momentum-based 2d platformer. There's no story, but there are over 4000 levels, every one of them handmade and varying in difficulty from really easy to really hard. Its amazing how consistently good the level design is. Myself, Ive only beaten a small chunk of them. There's also a level editor with level sharing capabilities. I love being able to create my own stuff, but that being said the editor UI feels very clunky and the level sharing in general is missing a lot of core features that really aught to exist (such as being able to save user levels for later, or delete your own published levels off the server).

Some people will find that the game is overall too simple, and that's fine. But what it does, it does really well in my opinion. Only other thing I can think to say bad about it is that navigating menus feels clunky and unintuitive, but this is overall a great game.

36434645.review:
Easily over 250 hours of content if you include all levels, attempting to collect all gold, and then begin going for the secret challenges in each level. There is simply an unparalleled amount of content here; you will not find more official content per dollar in a platformer (unless the game is, of course free, in which that ratio is infinite).
This, of course, only applies if you are a fan of the game itself. I can assure you; if you enjoy 2D platforming with a challenge level similar to that of more recent "difficulty revival" games, i.e. Super Meat Boy, VVVVVV, JumpJet Rex and especially Dustforce DX, you will love this game. 
The minimalist style is accompanied with extraordinarily tight and manipulable physics that, even a hundred hours in, you will still be using in new and varied ways. Each level has smart design that allows for multiple different playstyles and every obstacle contained within is usually placed in an intelligent, difficult-yet-fair manner. The sheer number of levels in the N++ Solo tab alone is enough to be worth 15 dollars, but there's seven times that in the final product (including the co-op and race modes).
This game is the quintessential platformer. It will chew you up and spit you out... and you'll love every second of it.

36075318.review:
After being a huge fan of the flash games N and N2, it was a real blast playing this latest incarnation... sadly my times on the leaderboards rank about the 13000 mark, meaning 12999 other people were faster than me, but that doesn't matter. Momentum-based platformers really impress me, and there is none finer than N++.


The minimalist design is still here, and the hand-crafted levels vary from simple to notoriously difficult.


There is nothing so difficult that it cannot be finished in 5 to 10 attempts, but the best thing about this game is the palpable sense of improvement (very much like Dustforce DX). I am about 50% through the main N++ stages, and I have enjoyed every second so far, the slowly morphing ambient background beats are so wonderful, that sometimes you simply forget they are playing (which is weird, as some are heavy on the bass, and I have a very decent subwoofer)... a sign of perfect music choice.


I know I have yet to hit the truly "difficult" stages, but I am not frightened. I actually look forward to them... which is not something often said about precision platformers.


I give this game a solid 9.5/10


It is only surpassed by the likes of Super Meat Boy and Dustforce DX, and mainly because of the randomness in difficulty of stages... not technically the game itself.


Whether it's shimmying up narrow gaps, or making seemingly impossible screen-wide jumps, this game is a real gem

35756312.review:
N++: The sequel to C++

N++ (also called NPlusPlus) is a twitchy little game. A proper sequel to the classic Flash-browser game N (also called N: The Way of the Ninja) which brings the game back to PC, unlike N+ (also called NPlus) which was an Xbox 360 and PS3 game, which never came to PC.

N++ Is ++ like the prior versions, but ++ better. It has ++ levels, including starter levels, the originals/legacy ones from N, all new ones for N++, and workshop/user made content. So you'll have ++ to do and complete. You can always complete a level normally, but to actually ace it, you'll need to collect every gold on every level to 100% it. You will need ++ time, ++ skills, and ++ anger management classes for how frustrating some levels and maps are.

This game is ++ skill and momentum based. You run, keep the momentum, jump, fall, slide-ish so you dont go splat on the floor, dodge missiles, dog like beeping electrical robots, gauss riffles, jump over mines, collect gold, and finish levels.

The game also has ++ "skins" and songs. By "skins", i mean the aspect of the game. the game can be black background, white outline, with red mines/missile/enemies, or green background, purple outline, with blue mines/missile/enemies. You get more by completing levels, and by doing complete vertical or horizontal row of levels.

Its a good game to play if bored, or waiting for something. A level (which is actually 5 maps in each level) can take anywhere from 10 minutes, to 30-40 minutes, depending on your skill and the difficulty of each map.

If, for some reason, you're unsure if this game is for you, there is always the original N online, which you can play for free from Chrome, Firefox or any other web browser. You can try that out, and if you like it, then N++ is your thing too. ++ content, ++ pretty, ++ challanging, and ++ good. Simply google "N the way of ninja" and you should find the official website.

34645078.review:
Metanet has redeemed themselves (mostly) with this game after pissing me off relentlessly with the original N, then churning out a piss-easy XBox 360 game (N+), and then ultimately ripping my soul from my body and shredding it with their upgrade to N (NReality.)

It took me 2.5 years to beat 95% of NReality, and then a computer crash wiped all of my data. The emotional turmoil I experienced after that was unprecedented. I subsequently rid my computer of anything resembling N and told myself I would never play it again.

But little did I know that I still had a registered account with Metanet, and one day I received an e-mail about N++ being on Steam. I was hesitant, to say the least, but the price seemed reasonable, and the game itself did look awesome. This was a chance for me to redeem myself, so I went for it.

The game is awesome. It's not as ruthless as NReality, but it's still a huge challenge. There are enough gimmicks and enough new elements that keep me engaged. They still have user created levels at the ready in case I decide to try out a level that someone else made, and the music is simply amazing.

This game really has a soul. Nice to see that Metanet did something good with it after they tore it from me.

Only negative I have about the game is that there's no online co-op. Co-op is strictly local, which is difficult when you're the only one in the household who plays games like this. But from what I understand, they had limited resources, and had to decided between EITHER online co-op or user-created levels. Given the choice, I'd say they chose correctly.

34227982.review:
Neutral review

A new but classic platforming game, already timeless. Very tight simple controls, huge amounts of interesting levels, different approaches to each level, high skill cap, minimalist but effective graphics, and a great soundtrack.

However I'm already running into a couple very frustrating issues. The hitboxes on the mines are pretty annoying, there are tons of times I'll graze on with my head and phase through but then my legs will somehow clip them from many pixels away, even though visually they look perfectly clear of the mine. Also some of the shocking obstacles feel inconsistent with how far they'll shock you from and it seems to depend on the direction they're moving. 

I really liked the gentle progression of difficulty in levels until I got to last level of A17 on the N++ set. I completed all the levels before it without ever needing more than 10 lives on any particular level, but now I'm stuck on this anomoly. What a horrible idea for a level... there are shock balls that follow you through tunnels and rooms, but you are unable to tell which way they'll move as they come out of the tunnel. They are released as you run too so the timing changes each time if you don't run it exactly the same.... you're stuck with waiting around for the orbs to line up just right so you can sneak through them. Or even waiting to release them so they're all grouped together to make your dodges just a little easier.... you get no cue whatsoever of which direction they'll go or the track each individual orb will follow. Sometimes they run along the walls, sometimes they stick out into space for a tile or two, and they're all mixed up.

I really hope this is just a one off. I was having a good time with the challenge until this specific level... I'll admit platforming is my achilles heel in gaming, yet the type of challenge this one level provides isn't compelling or intuitive in any way, it's just an annoyingly long waiting game, plain horrible in comparison to every single flawless level before it. I'll obviously move down to the B set and take some time and come back to this level later, but if the levels that follow in progression lead to more challenges specifically like this I'm really not interested in seeing what else the game has to offer further down the line.

34192277.review: Don't be deceived by the single-room levels made entirely in the in-game editor. N++ has finely tuned its subtle physics system and tileset to grant both the player and the level designer a remarkable level of freedom. The game's packed solid with levels that teach the mechanics *wordlessly*, to get you ready for the challenges that stretch those same mechanics to their very limit - and I haven't even scratched the surface of multiplayer! Add to that an extensive soundtrack plus tons of color schemes that you can switch between right from the start menu, and you've easily got the most finely tuned version of a platformer that's already proved it can withstand the test of time.

If you're a time attack/high score junkie, then this game may be right up your alley. 

If you're anyone who doesn't care about those things, though, you may find this game woefully empty of anything that might delight you or make you care about it. I will admit that I really liked the electronic soundtrack, and the "story" which you can access from the main menu was pretty cute and humorous. Other than that, though, I had no desire to play more than a small number of stages as it did not hook me in at all.

This game doesn't get as much publicity as I feel it should, so I'm writing a review. Other reviews (and the game's description) have already described the gameplay and mechanics.

If you want a taste of what the game is like, try the original N browser game (search "N game" on Google, requires Flash), it's still alive and well. N++ is certainly the definitive iteration, but you'll get a feel of what the momentum mechanic is like.

I partially bought this game because I played the original N game years ago (possibly why I mostly stick with the Vasquez  colour scheme and the soundtrack off), but it's a really good game regardless of that.

It's a really good platformer. It's a really cool game. I would recommend it!

33404028.review:
The game has inherited many features from its previous series (N and N plus). On the perspective by just looking at it, it's fun to play and the simple controls works great with keyboards. Your primary objective is to reach for the key card and find your way to the exit. If you want to, you may challenge yourself to collect all gold blocks in the level without dying. Its almost no different than any other platformers, but what makes it special is that it has very unique UI color schemes and awesome techno musics. The music helps you to concentrate while playing and you never feel bored. You kept dying again and again but in result you won't want to give up on playing anymore because you are so into the game by just listening the musics. The game also rewards you new color schemes after completing a certain number of stages and each of them is very pleasant looking. Clearly this game has a distinctive way to express its beauty.

The game is predicated on tough jumps and controls, and its very own physics system that's built on momentum. All you can really do with your ninja avatar is run and jump, but you must be able to use acceleration and precise leaps to land on your desired place. By trying to complete the level you will be experienceing countless deaths and resulting successes eventually makes you feel that you have really achieved a lot of things. The game tells you to complete each level within 90 seconds and picking up gold along the way to increase your timer. If you are to become a hardcore player (like me), you will likely want to collect all the gold up.

N++ has a huge number of campaign levels (2000+) and even more levels uploaded by the players all around the world. While I am still struggling on completing first part of Solo levels I still can't believe that my total play time has reached 5 hours(believe me, its not short compared to other games). The Co-op levels requires 2-4 players to play, and there will be parts where you have to kill yourself into hazards to make a way for your friend to reach to the exit. But usually it's pretty much the same with solo levels (sometimes you can complete a Co-op level all by yourself). You can also play the uploaded levels as well, or you can make levels of your own and upload them like others. Unfortunately it's a huge dissapointment that there is no online play for the Co-op levels.

N++ might lack online play and feel like more of the same, but it's pretty much everything a platformer fan could want out of a sequel. It's still challenging, it has sh*tloads of levels, and it's a hell of alot of fun to play.

There are 125 introductory levels, 500 N++ levels, 500 more levels for ultimate edition, 500 levels from the original N and N+, those levels in hardcore mode, 800 co-op levels, and 1025 race levels. All expertly hand-crafted with the length and height of every jump in mind. Not to mention, a level editor with Steam Workshop support which allows seemingly infinite user-created levels.
And as for the actual platforming gameplay, it's spot on, every death is your fault and your fault alone, the game never screws you over, well, it kind of does, but in a way you can learn from, you never feel cheated. The soundtrack is stellar as well. The race and co-op mode is an absolute blast. (especially the race mode) I really love this game and you should buy it right now.

32836429.review:
'N' (this game's in-browser predecessor) claimed innumerable hours of my early adolescence. If the past 48 hours are anything to go by, it seems that N++ poses a similar threat to my adulthood.

There are two things that really make N++ stand out from other instadeath-walljumping-platformers:

- Very beautiful minimalism (soundtrack also)
- Emphasis on harnessing retained momentum

The momentum thing is fun to learn but hard to explain. The game's colour scheme and soundtrack have a mind of their own, and this makes me happy.

Oh yeah also a third thing:

- tight level design

Some of the levels are easy and elegant, some of them are difficult and elegant. Basically in six hours I haven't played a level that I didn't enjoy. Obviously there's a lot of dying, but I'm yet to get frustrated. 

Cool yeah if you like platformers / difficult games / beautiful games you should get this.

32162035.review:
Let me tell you a story.

When I was a kid, back in the days when Steve Jobs was still alive, when I only barely understood where babies came from, when I read books about Forestclan and Firestar, when the only video game I actually physically owned was Myst, there were flash games. These were, mostly, the only games that you could share or show to other people. And among your Fancy Pants Man and Run, there was N. One little ninja VS a seemingly impossible number of levels, fueled by gold and a passion for juking rockets.

I played the eff out of it. And then, in time, I came to the edge of my abilities. The limits to my perseverence. Eventually, I stopped, but not before enjoying it half to death. There were a few other times, in later years, when I came back to it on a memory trip, downloaded it off the webpage, and kept a tally of deaths as I strived for 100% completion. But again, I eventually became overwhelmed by life and such.

And now N++ is here. Faster. Simpler. Bigger and, I will say, better. And now, with tunes. It is the essential N experience, and I am so happy it exists. I can feel myself entering that platforming Zen as I work my way though, a rock garden full of mines and golden flowers. And I continue to be reminded:

Simple does not mean Easy. Hard does not mean the opposite of Fun.

31843261.review:
N is a very tight, movement based platformer game. It offers a huge variety of levels on very different skill levels, varying from a casual experience to hardcore grinds to finish one.

First thing I've noticed after launching the game were modes, you have a standard singleplayer platformer experience, but that's not it. There's also a CO-OP mode and race mode. The co-op mode is self explanatory, you plug another controller in, and play along a friend, the level design in those is pretty good, you often need both players to survive, and even if not they're really helpful to have around. The race mode is a bit weird, and I didn't have the chance to get into it fully at least yet, so there's not much I can say about it, but there's plenty of levels in it too.

The main part though, is definitely the singleplayer experience, where you have 3 tabs full of levels as of now (Ultimate Edition) and also intro levels tab. There are a lot of levels starting At A and ending on E all having 20 episodes consisting of 5 stages each. Then after you finish all those you get to move along to X row which is basically an expert challenge. I personally dislike the idea behind the episodes, as you have to beat all 5 during one playthrough to get the progress done, because when you beat one the level progress doesn't save, and you have to start an episode over, but that's a minor flaw.

The game is also movement based. It takes a while to get used to the "slide-y" movement, but it's actually very tight, and feels good, not being floppy whatsoever. There are coins scattered throughout all the levels, and the ninja collects them to get some more time for finishing the episode, but those can often be skipped without paying much attention to, because there's usually plenty of time. You can also try to collect them all, as it's often fun to go through an alternate route to gather some, and they provide a pretty tough additional challenge, though I suggest going for them after beating an episode, as you can only access a particular level after beating said episode.

The graphics and music fit together very well. The minimalistic artstyle goes along greatly with this soundtrack. The electronic beats make a great "background noise". There are also plenty of themes to play around with, as you unlock them by beating episodes. Only thing I wish was added would be a theme editor, as I don't think it'd be hard to implement and some of the themes are just straight up bad(For example light blue menu with lighter blue text).

To sum it up, there are some things I have issues with, such as boring waiting game levels with tough parts near the end that basically test the limits of your patience, and the episodic nature of the world hub which doesn't allow for easy quitting, but overall, the game is very good, the movement feels amazing, the physics feel very good once you get used to them and the soundtrack is great.

31602163.review:
This is an augmented version of the freeware [url=http://www.thewayoftheninja.org/n.html]N[/url] (out there since 2004). Basically, an awesome game.

You control a ninja (!!!), who has to run through an [b]episode[/b] (a set of 5 levels). Each level is a chamber full of dangers / enemies, but the worst part is that you have a [b]lifetime[/b] (a timer set to 90 seconds). The risks are weighted by the presence of [b]gold[/b], and for each piece you grab your lifetime will increase by 2 seconds. Run, do acrobatics, dodge dangers, get gold (everyone loves gold, isnt it), find the exit, move to the next level. Your final score is your lifetime, and during an episode, the following level starts with the lifetime set to the score of your previous success (otherwise 90 secs, as mentioned before).

The graphic style is very minimal, but it just works fine. You will never have the feeling of playing a raw, bad-made game. Never.

The amount of episodes (remember, one episode is a set of 5 levels) is 225 (tremendous) and, if you still want some, there's an [b]editor[/b] and a database containing all community-made levels. Huge value.

It's a [b]challenging game[/b]; sometimes you will get mad. But all things considered, this is a platform, which has to be challenging by definition.

And now, the greatest question: Why pay for this game if it's only an augmented version of a freeware?
N++ has [b]enhanced graphics[/b] (color palettes that will make you crazy) [b]and sound effects[/b], a [b]soundtrack[/b] (a mix of cool electronic tracks that will make the game even more enjoyable) and more episodes than the free version. There is also a bunch of [b]new game-modes[/b] (multiplayer, race, hardcore mode). That's it.

Developers say this is the greatest platform of this time. They just might be right about it. Go for this game hands down, you won't be disappointed.

emmmm，参考了其他的很多评测，感觉自己的评测还是有必要改一下（但是会保留一部分原文
第一次玩N++的玩家可以尝试去了解一下N系列的历史，由于本人没有主机所以没办法玩到其中的一个版本。第一款N系列《N》为Flash游戏，相对于N++来说有优点也有缺点，优点的话可以从画面说说，一代的画面非常简洁，是的，如果你觉得N++的画面都很简单了，那N的话就让人觉得更加的干净，缺点的话，关卡数量过少且自制界面不如N++方便和更容易上手，其他的区别项就是N没有音乐。第二款N系列《N+》面向的平台是XBOX ONE（记得是），没有玩过的我也没法做出评价。以下是对一个差评的回应
1、音效很清晰，但音乐很普通，缺乏存在感。也许担心过于有动感的音乐会影响玩家的操作节奏？
1A：最后一句的确有道理，所以前一句个人认为不应该成为不推荐的理由，很多和N++相似的游戏的音乐一般都是为了衬托气氛，也很难能做出存在感爆表的音乐
2、虽然各种机关和陷阱不难理解，但几乎完全没有提示和描述还是不好
2A：担心这个问题而犹豫入手的可以先尝试研究一代，机关数量少且机关的外形容易理解，刚入手N++时我也有些认不清一些以前就有过的机关
3、服务器有些问题，经常链接不上。导致看不到其他玩家创作的地图。
3A：小游戏的服务器不用指望服务器了
4、完全没有考虑过休闲玩家的心态！！以收集和时间来统计分数很正常，你用计分条不好么？非要用计分槽？还TMD搞那么明显放在屏幕正上面！还TMD是从不满开始的！！
4A：一个游戏的续作总是会保留一些元素的，我认为这种计分槽就是这游戏的精髓，详情请参考前作
有一些同类游戏通病并且无法解决的问题我认为并不是不推荐的理由，就像晕3D的人在所有3D游戏里全给不推荐一样
引用一个评测结尾：“喜欢N的朋友，不买等于亏了一个亿”

31473274.review:
I might suggest that some people get this game only while it's on sale. However, I do believe it is worth the price in spite of only having played the solo gamemode in my nine hours so far.

This game is nothing graphically, but the level design and music are where it shines. The level design is perfect at inducing a sense of flow along with the music. Without having to collect the gold pieces or to beat levels quickly or to beat levels in a gauntlet without dying, it's an easy game for people who want to play it casually. Collecting the gold often forces a player to carefully balance their movement with two or more mechanics at once, and it's implemented brilliantly. For example, many levels require you to carefully balance on blocks that move with your weight as a laser homes in on you. Each level has a sense of motif, and challenge feels well-rewarded. Plenty of times a challenge ahead of me seemed tough, but not impossible, and the game has lulled me into spending 30+ minutes on specific levels to prove myself.

Pros:
-Great accessibility for challenge-seekers and people who want to instantly delve into gameplay
-Also a great game for casuals
-Music
-Designed with flow in mind
-Level names are funny
-Instantly launches the player back into the action after he dies

Cons:
-Few types of obstacles exist in the game, and though all of them are used amazingly and in different ways throughout the game, there could be some more.
-LET ME GET THAT LAST GOLD PIECE. D:<

31325461.review:
N – слепленный на флэше в 2004-ом году бесплатный браузерный платформер.   Его механика была проста как никогда – вы просто прыгаете и избегаете разнообразных препятствий. Сюжет прост как два пальца: вы – ниндзя. Вы умеете высоко прыгать. На одном уровне вы можете жить не более 90 секунд. Действуйте.

N++ - прокачанная версия оригинальной игры. Суть не изменилась от слова «совсем». В вашем распоряжении всё так же исключительно кнопки передвижения и прыжка. История всё так же умещается на одном экранчике в меню. Посмотрите второй трейлер на страничке игры. Разработчики хвастаются тем, чего в их игре нет. Необычно, не правда ли?

N++ - пик развития концепции «минимализм во всём», при котором контента в 619 мб не меньше чем в 40-гиговой РПГ. На выбор 4 режима: соло-прохождение, содержащее в себе несколько компаний из сотен уровней каждый, хардкор – местная НГ+, прохождение на время и локальный кооп. Редактор уровней для желающих самостоятельно устроить себе баттхерт. Общее количество уровней переваливает за четырёхзначное число. Количество требуемых на прохождение часов уходит далеко за трёхзначное.

И на протяжении всего этого времени игра ни разу не надоедает и вызывает приступы долгих залипаний. Есть уровень – на уровне есть золото и самые разнообразные преграды. На прохождение даётся 90 секунд. Каждая преграда убивает одним прикосновением.  Сложность – от «ой, спокойно с первого раза прошёл» до «ДА [CENSORED] КАААААК!?!?!?!». Каждая смерть вызывает мысль «Ну вот счас ещё раз попробую и всё».
 
Тонна хардкорного и затягивающего контента под обликом слепленной на коленке запредельно минималистичной игры.  Посвящается всем любителям сложностей и просто качественных платформеров с вылизанной до идеала механикой.

31323803.review:
Incredible game. You may think the style is extremy simple and you know what, you're right! Its simple yet its so charming, you get tons of different palletes to choose from, different colors for your ninja and some accessories, the customization here for the levels alone is pretty damn solid that there's bound to be one that interests pretty much everyone, in general they have rather contrasting colors to have the level stand out. I think if it wasn't for such a simple artstyle, the developers not have as much content in the game, its a good compromise in my opinion. 

Controls are solid, I mean SOLID. It has a floaty feeling yet has finesse and precision. You feel like you have complete control over when your character starts and stops both up and down and left and right, I have yet to find a game that manages to balance it out as well as this one does. The momentum mechanic works really well, your character feels like it has force applied to it when you run and jump, jumping off of walls and gaining speed. Its so satisfiying!

The amount of content you get for this game is absurd, I've already put 5 hours into it and I haven't even scratched the surface of what this game has to offer. It does not descriminate, whatever way you choose to play is here. Want to speedrun? Got it, collect them all for that completionist side of you? Right here! Want to take it nice and steady, go at at reasonable pace and not care about speedrunning or collecting? The game has you covered, in fact the time it gives to complete a level is generous, I have not once found myself even when I was taking my sweet sweet time to fail a level because the timer ran out. The developers promise 100+ hours and so far I believe them on that, even just completing the solo mode itself will take you I'd say a solid 20-30 hours if you don't touch the rest of the content or collect anything and just rush through it, you've already got more than what you paid for. Heck I remember when we paid 60 dollars for triple A games for 8 hours. 8 HOURS!

Besides the solo mode as I mentioned it also has hardcore which is basically your time attack mode in which you try to complete a level as fat as possible, you're given a reasonable starting time and from there it stacks if you collect the orange squares. Feeling brave? Do hardcore without going for the orange squares and that right there will be an extra challenge.

THEN, you also have the level creator, yes I am not done yet. You've got thousands upon thousands of user made levels, granted some of them aren't up to snuff with the content the devs provided, it further expands the playability of this game beyond what you'd imagine for a 15 dollar game.

Have I mentioned the soundtrack yet? No? Well I must!!! The soundtrack is absolutly superb, its a combination of electronic with slow relaxed drum and base tones with some occasional chillstep, it is incredible, it really goes hand in hand with the gameplay.

Don't miss this game! I nearly gave it a pass because I thought it was going to be a rather bland experience yet everytime I jump in, I feel so compelled to sink hours of my life into it. Like a tube of pringles, once you start you won't stop. ;)

Score: 10/10. Don't miss this gem of a game!

31289554.review:
[h1]Does the world need more platformer? Not after this.[/h1]
游戏本身手感和素质都挺高，当然也相当硬核，游戏梯度设计的不错，到了后面的关卡就不那么简单了。很多地方你想要更快过关或者全收集，需要提前想好策略，也不能出半点差池。
这款游戏昨天刚刚出了大版本更新，加入了很多新的内容，也很良心的没有做成 DLC 来卖。现在打折只要24块钱，非常推荐入手。
如果你曾有过对平台动作游戏灰心，不妨来玩一玩这款游戏，他会教你脱离萌新；如果你本身是平台游戏硬核玩家，千万不要错过。

[h1]TL;DR.[/h1]
大概是小学的时候，刚刚接触电脑，获取游戏的途径多数都是4399的 Flash 游戏。在某一天搜寻游戏的时候，偶遇了这款 [b]N++[/b] 的前身 [b]N[/b]。其实名字很容易让人忽略掉，好在有游戏截图和演示。里面是一个人这摸样的角色飞檐走壁，吃掉硬币躲开攻击最后成功抵达终点。算下来这算是我接触的第一款硬核跳台游戏吧[spoiler]？[/spoiler]。当时就玩了几关，就喜欢上了这款游戏，以至于我把那款 Flash 游戏下载到我的 U 盘里面，上微机课总会打开来挑战几关。当时手残的我[spoiler]现在仍然是[/spoiler]很害怕遇到火箭、浮台之类的关卡，最后终于被我全部通关。后来发现了 Ngame 的贴吧[spoiler]现在早已鸠占鹊巢[/spoiler]，里面有很多自定义关卡，看到那里才知道，原来游戏内置的关卡是多么简单。可惜的是通关不久后我把当时那个 U 盘丢了，再后来这游戏出了续作 [b]N+[/b]，但是只支持了几个主机平台，到此为止只能和这款陪我度过了很多微机课的游戏暂时告别。去年8月，突然发现 [b]N++[/b] 这个名字居然出现在了浏览队列里面，果然是又一部续作，终于补上了隔了这么多年的机票。只是早已经没有了当时玩 [b]N[/b] 的激情，放在库里做个纪念吧。我在写这篇评测之前又去找了一下，找到了 [b]N[/b] 的[url=http://www.thewayoftheninja.org/n.html]下载网站[/url]，如果看到这里的看官们有兴趣，不妨去体验一下。
写到这里，算是对这款游戏十年的陪伴的致敬，也算是对逝去的青春的怀念。

31283011.review:
Be forewarned if you're a perfectionist and bad at platformers, you might consider giving this a miss.

The game has an absolute plethora of single player levels to explore, the good news being anybody can tackle a moderate amount of levels and still get their moneys worth without pulling their hair out. The bad news here being they are laid out as episodes, a set of 5 levels meshed into 1 falling into a category; A, B, C, D, E and X (A considered easiest, X for Expert) and while an episode starts out easy you are required to complete it in order to revisit or select any level at will, this can be frustrating for end levels as they are commonly the most challenging.

Since Ultimate Edition just got released earlier today I have to say the level set has expanded exponentially, the hardcore episodes are under their ultimate category and should be undertaken with more caution, as I imagine they're more fiendish than anything seen prior. Hardcore stories also came with this edition and now you're on a timer which will not reset upon death, with an endless ticking clock and gold only counted when you reach the exit this new mode is for the side of players who enjoy greater challenge. I am not be recommending this for casual gamers because this is essentially a huge chunk of time per each column with no guarantee you'll make it in time or beat the column at all, with that said I also ask potential buyers to consider this.

As for obstacles the game really does a decent job of being fair the vast majority of the time, I can't rate them as best or worst because the way they are laid out per level ranges depending on the level in question. A few things worth noting is that obstacles do combine for greater challenge (pro?) however they are very limited in scope, as other reviewers mention when you go so far in you've seen most of what's in store (con, enemy/obstacle limited variety).

Metanet overall does a really good job especially considering certain gold requires momentum to obtain, they also make an all gold level challenging however I fear the design choice to have an all gold achievement be for every level in solo to be a tease, so achievement hunters I would not recommend this product to you as you may never get them all.

Game does inclue legacy, which is a 'best of' previous titles levels, this means anybody who has played or does play the previous titles will remember these levels fondly or grimace at seeing them again, I myself enjoyed a good throwback to the flash games levels and am pleased to regard them as good as the plusplus, I skipped N+ so can't speak for that. 

I am inclined to mention the user levels are present and are admittedly the most challenging found in game for me personally, they can range from fair to downright BS unfair and the main pro here is that any steam level can be played if you can find and they're not laid out in episode format so for a quick blast on the game or a pick me up every now and again they are the best addtion provided you keep within your skill range and know when to give up.

All of this is based on my personal experiences and I am inclined to admit some may view my opinion as biased as I am a fan of the game and hold it in high regard, I don't think it would be an understatement to say it has the best platformer experience if you're not put off by its appearance and if you can appreciate the little things then this game is a little gem that will certainly go a long way, if the idea of running faster to jump higher and do things quicker isn't for you skip this.

31199612.review:
Tried to give this game a fair chance, but I'm absolutely not compelled to play it any more.

N++ is another game from the curiously popular and fondly remembered N franchise that focuses on platforming in its raw application. Controlling  a nondescript ninja, you try to reach the goal on bit-sized minimalistic levels with scarce art, electronic music and gameplay mechanics focused on gaining momentum and precision jumps around various deathtraps. This is as simple as you can get... and unfortunately it's not enough for me.

While seeing the spreadsheet-sized level selection, I cannot really find any reason to continue finishing it. This is mostly because after 4-5 hours you basically saw all interesting content in the game or at least you feel it that way. All enemies, all blocks, all basic mechanics are learned. From that point only thing that change is the ramping up difficulty and unlockable color pallets, some of which by the way, are absolutely confusing. N++ is just an endless conveyor belt of levels, each less interesting and exciting than the previous one which in the end makes completion very unsatisfing. Thanks to limited size of them and low amount of different enemies and objects, game gets stale extremely fast. You simply cannot magically conjure mass of interesting levels with so many limiting factors. Because of this N++ seems to be stuck mentally in its flash-game roots where you played it only because there wasn't any particular alternative and you just had 5 minutes of spare time.

In short, N++'s minimalist approach is more of a curse than a blessing. I believe that only people who are genuinely into extremely challenging, simple platformers that don't mind the barren presentation and lack of variety, will be satisfied. I'm not in the mood of proving my platforming skill to anybody and if you also don't feel grabbed by looking at the gameplay and screenshots... Simply don't bother.

30759783.review:
Note: I don't know why it says I've only played this for 11 hours - I keep getting server problems which might be to blame. I have also played this for about 20 hours on the PS4.

If you play this game, you will die. You think you died in Bloodborne? You think the bosses in Dark Souls 3 can kill you in a couple of hits? Lol. Just lol. People complaining that other games kill them too easily have never played N++. This is a game so nightmarishly difficult that, according to websites which track Steam achievements, no-one has obtained some of the achievements in N++. No-one. Worldwide. And it's the same on the PS4. 

This does not mean the achievements are "exclusive", it means the game has been designed in such a way that people simply cannot get them, which is poor design - what's the point in having achievements nobody can actually achieve? If you try some of the later levels you may well find some of them impossible, or simply too annoying. The maps with lots of "evil clones" of your character in particular are very frustrating. Some maps are so overloaded with moving things that I start feeling migrainey and struggle to "understand" the map. Missiles are no longer the only things that will kill a skilled player.

If you liked N+ and have waited impatiently for a sequel, this is its bigger, badder brother. The way each element is employed in N++ results in a tougher and longer experience (although including N+'s maps seems like a cheap way to claim "we have over a thousand levels"). 

The physics seem a bit improved, but realistically, I find they don't make too much sense, and you can die in unexpected ways, such as hitting a ramp at speed (which will either kill you or save your life). The annoying bouncing boxes with their weird effect on your jumping are still present. I'm quite good at the game (although far from a world-beater) and have got pretty far, and I reckon at least half of all my deaths have been due to the weird, annoying physics, which can cause the controls to be unresponsive for a split second and your ninja to move in unexpected ways. Clipping a wall with your feet does this a lot. Your ninja is not particularly nimble. However, if you thought the way momentum works in the original Super Mario Brothers was superlative, you will love the physics of N++. (Cue someone pretending to be a physics professor who will elaborate on how "accurate" and "convincing" the game is.)

Note that nothing else in the game is affected by the physics, so you still see rockets performing super-tight turns which you will never match, and the reload time for a new missile is still less than a second.

There are a ton of secrets in the game but I think most people will miss nearly all of them. You can unlock a super-hard swathe of maps if you complete every single level in the game, although again, most people will have given up far before this point. Not every map or episode has walkthroughs on Youtube if that's your bag, so again, you lose out. I am led to believe that some of the "secrets" are simply harder versions of existing maps, and if that's correct, is it really worth bothering with?

The map editor is a bit overwhelming, I didn't find it nearly as simple or intuitive as N+'s, but if you can harness it, you will be able to make some truly stunning efforts. A pity there appears to be no real management of user content online as most of the maps are simply impossible for the average (or even the good) player. It would be brilliant if there was an option to play or download easier episodes, so you can just kick back and have fun. Still, you can make some genuinely fun stuff for your friends. I haven't uploaded anything yet so don't know if you can do an episode, as you could in N+.

So why am I giving this the thumbs up? Well, I'll go on record as saying at least 75% of the maps range from being quite enjoyable to downright amazing to play. The sheer scale of imagination, when the game is actually built from very few components, is stunning. Even the moronically difficult maps, the ones which bring your enjoyment to a crashing halt, are so well designed they border on genius. I can overlook the sometimes questionable physics and the weird momentum quirks if the maps are fast-paced and exciting enough. Playing with friends, even if they just spectate, can be hilarious, and defeating a particularly trollworthy map feels epic beyond belief. Easy maps can make you look like some kind of genius player, and for all the bad luck you'll have, the occasional snatch of brilliant luck can make for a superb replay.

Tl;dr - flawed, occasionally super-hard well past the point of deliberate trolling, but extremely fun, engaging and exciting, with a very powerful level editor. It's the perfect way to kill a spare ten minutes. Or two hours. Just mind those missiles.

30521618.review:
I'll admit I got this from a Humble Bundle, not for the full price.

For what it's worth though, N++ is a momentum-based platformer - think Super Meat Boy on steroids, but with less blood and more gold. Also less rage, though by no means easy.

Also: THERE. ARE. SO. MANY. LEVELS. There's over 100 of these "episodes", each of which is 5 levels. That's well over 500 (the description boasts of a whopping 2360 levels - and I don't doubt that they're there), and that's just the singleplayer campaign - if you have a friend (or three) or happen to be super good at controlling two characters (playing too much Fireboy and Water Girl games recently?) there's a co-op campaign as well, though with less "episodes". And then there's a level creator, just in case you thought the devs didn't put enough content in the game (they did).

The momentum-based platforming makes the Ninja a bit difficult to master, since he seems rather slippery and awkward at first, but feels very rewarding once you figure out how it works. Eventually you start understanding it and you'll be flying about the stages like nobody's business... then you hit a mine and try again :P


TL; DR: The best physics in a platformer in all my years, and the game is designed perfectly around that. I'd also go as far as to say the best platformer I have ever played. If you want a straight platformer, N++ is the way to go. Nothing else even comes close.

30318050.review:
As a N-game veteran and big fan (Played old Nv1.4, N-reality and Nv2) this was next logical step in my path of the ninja. I highly recommend this game, if you played and enjoyed older flash versions of this game. It's challenging platformer and it may seem hard at first, but it gets better, when you improve, but also harder levels will come and some maps in later rows was really hard even for me (I completed all N-reality and Nv2 metanet levels)

Story is really simple: It's you (ninja) in a room full of enemies and your only goal is to get door key and get to door to continue your adventure in next level. You can either play through official episodes, where you need to complete 5 levels in a row to unlock next episode, or you can play user-created levels, which are in all forms of difficulty/playability.

Official metanet levels are very good and mostly with fine difficulty. You can either just complete it, which is usually not too hard, but if you get better you can try to go for all gold runs, which are the real challenge, especially in some harder maps. Psychics and objects/enemies are well-thought out to make maps interesting to keep playing. There is enough content to play it for days and even if you complete all episodes, there are always some new cool userlevels. And it also has race mode and multiplayer co-op episodes. (Unfortunately you can only do co-op with 2 players on 1 computer) There are more enemies than in previous versions, some are really cool (Portal, that spawns evil ninja, who will chase you mirroring your moves and you die, if he catches you) You will soon figure best way to survive against certain enemies.

I really like N++, it's better than older N games with lot more content, cool new enemies,  and lot of fun. Thanks metanet software for making this game, as I said I'm a long time fan of N the way of the ninja series. Probably only things I don't like much are that some levels are too hard  to get all gold for me, but I know it's supposed to be challenge. And when rocket crashes near you, you suddenly don't see anything and can easily make a mistake.

If you liked any older N game version, get N++ for sure, you won't regret it. And if you never played game like this before, try it too, it has simple old school graphics, but there is great amount of content for that price and lot of options, how to play the game. (Simply complete maps, go for all gold runs, or even try to go for episode/level highscores)

30292130.review:
[h1]N++ DOPEST PLATFORMER AROUND!!![/h1]

[b]Presentation[/b]
Straight from the get go this game has great aesthetics and an even better soundtrack. It builds upon the classic style dating all the way back to the first iteration of N but gives you a plethora of color pallets to choose from in a slick UI. Very minimalist but beautiful to look at none the less. The soundtrack suits the frenetic and super challenging gameplay well and is one of the best I have heard in recent years, up there with the likes of the more recent furi and timeless hotline miami series. 

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Expect to die a lot. This is the kind of game where you will die... again... and again. It demands perfection and when you get it right it just feels so good. The controls are momentum based and once you get used to them give you a lot of freedom to move around the level with certain restrictions that keep it challenging such as height and speed... I've killed myself running into a wall too fast.

[b]Content[/b]
If you have played older versions of this and are wondering if you should pick it up or not... I would say if you are a fan absolutely. Its got all the levels from previous versions N and N+ and a whole slew of new levels, developer made and fan made. There is steam workshop integration with a built in level editor so essentially you will never run out of new things to play. It is the most complete version of the game and is packed to the brim with old and new content.

[b]CONCLUSION[/b]
This is not an easy game but damn is it a fun game. The multiplayer, whether versus or coop, Is a blast. The single player seems endless with how many levels there are. It expands upon previous iterations on just about any way imaginable and it does what it does well. If you have played the older games and enjoyed them pick it up immediately... if you havent do yourself a favor and start now.

30205515.review:
Sólo el mismísimo Lucifer pondría daño por caída en un plataformas 2D, 10/10.

Ahora mismo que escribo esto, tengo poco más de 3 horas clockeadas, pero sin embargo ahora mismo me parece el mejor plataformer 2D disponible en Steam. Recuerda mucho a Super Meat Boy, es un plataformer 2D muy desafiante el cual cuenta con cientos y cientos de niveles los cuales en algún punto harán que te den ganas de tirar el mando por la ventana, puedes completar los niveles de la forma que más te convenga (Simplemente yendo hacia tu objetivo o consiguiendo todos los colectibles del nivel). Lo único que echaría de menos sería la genial banda sonora por parte de Danny Baranowsky, pero la banda sonora por parte de una gran cantidad de artistas de electrónica también está muy bien. Pero aún así logra diferenciarse bastante bien, como por ejemplo en sus controles, los cuales no sientes que estás corriendo con los pies huntados en mantequilla, y muchos de tus movimientos se basan más en controlar el ímpetu de tu personaje que en hacer movimientos super precisos y viceversa.

Los niveles se agrupan de a cinco por fase, lo cual está bien si quieres por ejemplo completar una fase por sesión y tal, pero hay algunas fases en las cual los niveles se hacen muy largos y querrías por ejemplo guardar para poder completar ese nivel en específico más tarde. No es muy molesto, pero quizás sea un contra muy importante para algunas personas. También cuenta con multijugador local y dos modos de juego, lo cual de momento no he probado por que no tengo amigos :D, pero seguro también está muy bien.

Cabe mencionar que los gráficos son geniales, cuenta con arte minimalista y colores planos los cuales puedes ir cambiando por nivel.

Y poco más que decir, si eres un fanático de los videojuegos de plataformas, este es un must-have.

30158681.review:
여러분들은 아마 이런 종류의 게임을 옛날, 또는 몇일전에[url=http://www.stickpage.com/ngameplay.shtml]스X페이지[/url]에서 해보셨거나 [url=http://fg.gameangel.com/102000000000015202]게X엔젤[/url]에서 해보셨을 겁니다. 


저도 약 4~6년전에 저 사이트중에서 한번 해본적이 있었는데요. 그 당시에는 이게임이 어려운데도 불구하고 맨날 친가에 놀라갈 때면 항상 컴퓨터를 키면서 이 'N' 이라는 게임을 주구장창 했었죠. 1~3시간을 그때는 이게임만 했었답니다.

[h1]근데 컴퓨터를 끄면 지금까지 한 기록이 다 날라갔답니다. OTL [/h1]

어쨋든 이 게임에 대해 평가를 하면


[h1]○새로워진 적들[/h1]
전작에 비해 조금더 새로운 적이 생겼습니다. 아마 여러분들이 플레이하시면서 만나보실텐데요.
그중 적들을 몇몇 적어드리겠습니다.

1. 추적하는 드론(Deathball)
플레이어를 계속 쫓아 다니지만, 장애물이 있을시에는 따라다니지 못합니다.

2.더욱 작아진 잽 드론 (Micro Drone)
전작'n'을 하시면서 항상 경로로만 움직이는 애들이 더 작고 빠르게 나타났습니다.

3.대기형 지뢰 (Toggle Mine)
지뢰가 이제 지나가기만 하면 설치되는 형식으로 새로 생겼습니다.
물론 그냥 지뢰도 있습니다.

4.악마의 닌자 (Evil Ninja)
블랙홀모양으로 생겼는데 이 구멍을 지나가시면 뒤에 캐릭터랑 똑같은 놈이 계속 따라옵니다.
서로 부딪히면 주인공은 죽습니다.

5.지속 레이저 발사형 고정드론(Laser Drone)
고정드론이 360도를 회전하면서 다닙니다.
않움직이는 경우도 있지만 경로 이동에 거슬리는 놈이죠

6.쇼브 쓰웜프(Shove Thwump)
4면의 벽이 있는데 그중 밟은쪽 반대로 날라갑니다.

참고로 레이저드론은 전작보다 재장전 속도가 빨라졌습니다.

[h1]○달라진거 없는 UI[/h1]
인터페이스는 딱히 특별한점이 없습니다.  다만 시작버튼들이 오른쪽에서 왼쪽으로 옮겨졌습니다.
또, 시작시 나오는 플레이장면이 여전히 나옵니다. 다만 절대로 성공하는 장면은 찾기 어려우실 겁니다.

그래서 더욱 좋습니다.
게임하다가 멘탈이 나가면 시작화면에서 혼자 고생하는 n을 보면서 '내가 쟤보단 잘하겠지'라는 긍정마인드를 가질 수 있게하니깐요.

[h1]○새로운 색깔, 음악맞춤[/h1]
Left 쉬프트를 누르시면 색깔과 음악을 정하실 수 있는 창이 나타납니다.
아마 수십가지의 음악과 색깔들을 맞추실 수 있으며 결과는 인터페이스에서 혼자 움직이는 캐릭터와 배경을 보시면서 알아서 맞추시면 됩니다.

(그냥 'n'은 음악이 없습니다.)

[h1]○NEO틱하고,더욱 깔끔해진그래픽[/h1]
이번 N++가 더욱 깔끔하고 렉이 없는 게임으로 나욌습니다.
스크린샷에 나왔듯이 더욱 세련된 게임 퀄리티를 구입후 직접 느끼실 수 있습니다.

[h1]○너무 간단해진 듀토리얼[/h1]
전작에는 직접 유닛들이 화면에 나와가지고 예시를 보여주는가 하면
이번 편은 영어와 이런 적들을 피하라는 내용만 나옵니다.
(위에 있는 사이트로 직접 해보세요. 듀토리얼이 확실히 다를겁니다.)

[h1]○조금더 리얼리티해지고, 새로 나온 오브젝트들[/h1]
이제는 런치패드를 밟고 얼마 안되는 천장에 닿으면 그냥 죽습니다.
아무래도 우리 주인공에게 뼈와 골절을 준듯 합니다.
그리고 우리주인공에게 머리밴드가 생겼습니다.
목도리인줄 알았더니 아니였군요.
또한 그 시체는 지뢰에 계속 터지고 터지며 날라댕깁니다.
[b]불쌍한 우리'N' 심지어 목도 없어졌는데..[/b]
또 무슨 오브젝트들이 몇몇 생긴것 같은데, 정확히는 모르겠습니다.

[h1]○새로 생긴 Co-op,레이스 시스템[/h1]
이기능은 제가 잘 모르지만, 최대 4명정도로 아마 한 컴퓨터에 4명이 할 수 있습니다.
참고로 레이스모드에서는 도발이 가능합니다.


[h1]○아쉬운 타임리밋 장면[/h1]
N++는 전작에 비해 시간이 다되면 특별한 장면이 나오지 않습니다.
전작을 해보시면서 시간 다되가지고 실패한 유저들분들은 어떤의미인지 아실 듯 합니다.
캐릭터가 술을 마시는 장면이 나옵니다.

[h1]○새로운 창작기능[/h1]
보통 이런 게임들은 창작모드가 있으면 매우 꿀입니다.

30153636.review: Addictive, well rounded, clever little game that's actually not so little when you really get into the deeply hard and frustratingly clever shit. I havent fell in love with a game that quickly in a while, it feels really refreshing.

30146029.review:
Look, I haven't played this game much on Steam, but I have on...um...another platform. I've played it for close to 100 hours.

There are a few negative reviews that raise some concerns. I'm going to boil them down to a few words and respond.

Too hard: yes, the game is difficult, especially later on. That's the point. Like Super Meat Boy or other similar platformers, the game is easy-ish early on while you become comfortable with the controls and learn what all of the traps do. If you persist into the late game, you are going to die a lot, and you will spend absurd amounts of time on individual levels. But holy crap does it feel good to complete those levels.

Repetitive, difficulty doesn't rise enough, physics feel wrong: these criticisms are decently fair, although I don't think the game is repetitive. This game has a LOT of levels, so getting to the most difficult levels will take some time. As for the physics: either you like them or you don't. The way it works is very deliberate, and it came to eventually feel great for me.

Free similar flash games out there: I don't typically browse around the free available flash games out there, but as I noted above, there is an absurd amount of content in this game. And once you start getting into some of the hidden things, you'll really come to appreciate the level design. Everything is incredibly well-designed - you'll notice how perfectly places some traps are, which are meant to make you pay attention when you're trying to get through a level.

I can't sing the praises of the game highly enough.

30140600.review:
This is the best platformer ever made, without question. I spent days and days playing the original N while I was supposed to be working on my thesis. This version is a great update, with so. many. levels. I've apparently got 45 hours in, and I haven't finished much more than half  of them.

I'm not usually completionist on games - I like to beat the levels and move on. I never care about achievements and easter eggs (unless maybe the story is absolutely phenomenal). I also never care about posting better times? With this game, the additional goal of collecting all of the gold on each level is just perfect - simple, sometimes easy, often infuriating.

I don't even need the co-op and race modes to make this game great, and I could just ignore them, but I'll probably give them a try. Other extra features, similarly don't get in the way at all. If I just want to play the (newer, more fun) puzzles as in the old game, I can do that.

30130545.review:
N++ is an amazing platformer game. Fans of Super Meat Boy and the like will enjoy its hard difficulty and the insane amount of levels the game has to offer (2,360 of them, as a matter of fact, [i]not including user-made levels (!)[/i]). The physics can take a bit of getting used to, as N++ feels a little floatier than Super Meat Boy and other platformers, but gameplay is very fluid  overall. The pacing varies from level to level, ranging from careful and methodical planning to "run-as-fast-as-you-freaking-can", and resetting a level from the inevitable death or two (hundred) is almost instant. The art style is very crisp and not too busy for the eyes, and the range of colors that you unlock as you progress through the game give you something different to look at, which helps in changing things up and keeping the game looking fresh.
To top it off, the soundtrack is perfect for a game like N++. The soundtrack is an assortment of ambient IDM-style tracks which all manage to pull off the difficult task of giving the game atmosphere while not being distracting at the same time. Also, as mentioned above, there are user-created levels for those looking for a challenge or something new. N++ also has a cooperative mode and a competitive racing mode (local only).

For fans of the previous N games, this game is a no-brainer. This game is a must-have for fans of difficult platformer games. I highly recommend this game. 10/10

30127287.review:
You have to give some of yourself to this game, but it will give you so much in return. It's as deep and as hard as you want it to be. There has never been a platformer with more rewarding physics.


Please forgive its sometimes-clunky menus.


A couple things to be aware of:

- The userlevel community is great! It's easy to just totally not notice behind the innocuous-looking "Browse" menu item, but making levels, playing new levels as they come in, and competing on the weekly featured levels are where I spend easily half my time with the game. Don't miss it!

- If you care about high scores, which is a great thing to do, make sure you turn on the "submit level scores" option so you don't lose your level runs when you do full episodes. It's kind of a historical accident that it defaults to off. Hopefully this will be fixed in the next update.

- Race mode and Coop are *really good*. There's no online multiplayer, so you'll have to find someone to play with, but they are good enough that some hardcore players have literally flown internationally to play with each other :D

- Come hang out with us in the public discord! There's a level of the day for high scoring, userlevel contests, frequent streams by high level players, and general discussion and friendliness.

30092240.review:
UPDATE: This was a thumbs down review, but I changed it to a thumbs up because the developer actually took the time to read my review and reply to me. We need more developers in the game industry that actually care what the community thinks. Kudos to you man!

I was on the fence with this game.

I played the first N+ for hours and absolutely loved it. Now that I've played this game for quite some time I will try to point out the main differences that I see and feel in the game as quickly as possible.

Controls:  
-Jumping is inconsistent at times
-Games seems more slippery(ie sliding into bombs when trying to stop)
-Good news is you can jump on pointy geometry now

Objects:
-Missiles have a tighter turn radius, which was just annoying in my opinion
-Bombs are bigger and have a active/inactive state to them
-Bouncy Blocks are WAY different from the first game. Different point at which to jump to get maximum lift

Hit detection: This part I think is what frustrated me the most, apart from the controls not being consistent. I found that the top of your character is not really the top of your character.  It's almost as if your head doesn't count as part of your body. This is nice for some levels, but more frustrating than it is helpful.  You can no longer graze a switch with the top of your head and have it activate. Your movements need to be more explicit when hitting time and switches.

Collecting Time: I found myself never needing to go after time which made the game easier than I was hoping. I can only remember 1 time when I NEEDED to get some time or I wasn't going to complete the level. Most of the challenging parts of the levels you can skip because they involve collecting time that your really don't need.  The only reason to go for it is to get higher on the leader board. 

The developer did include the legacy levels from the first game in this one which I have to commend. 

Overall it's not a bad game, its just different from the first game in ways that are frustrating more than challenging and fun.

I would recommend you buy this game on sale if you want a challenging platformer.

 [*] Kaçmanız gereken objelerin çeşitliliği harikulade. Özellikle kendi ilizyonunuzdan kaçmayı kim akıl ettiyse onun ben ta...... İnanılmaz yaratıcı bir fikir.

29784105.review:
Das Spiel war ein Beifang in einem Humblebundle. Ich hatte einen Plattformer im Stile von Super Meat Boy erwartet und war anfangs recht zufrieden damit. Die anfängliche Euphorie ließ aber schnell nach und wandelte sich rasch in Frust. Viel zu viel Frust. 
Statt wie bei SMB so schnell wie möglich von A nach B zu kommen, liegt der Fokus hier eher im Aufsammeln von "Goldstücken". Das wäre ja alles okay, wenn die Goldstücke auf dem Weg zu finden sind (einige der besseren Level in diesem Spiel machen es genau so), meist muss man aber irgendwelche absurden Sprünge ausführen, manchmal sogar mehrfach, weil man nicht alle Goldstücke auf einmal erwischen kann, was sich natürlich negativ auf den Spielfluss auswirkt. Das ganze kann man natürlich auch als Challenge für sich selbst interpretieren und wenn man keine Lust hat, kann man es auch lassen, sozusagen wird das Spiel schwerer je mehr man erreichen will. 
Ein weiterer Makel des Spiels ist, dass es viel zu sehr auf Präzision setzt. Planung und Reaktionsvermögen spielen natürlich immernoch eine Rolle, aber das alles nutzt natürlich nichts, wenn man die Sprünge nicht so schafft, wie man es möchte. Und die Steuerung ist, was das angeht, sehr empfindlich, was dazu führt, dass man ständig stirbt, ohne besser zu werden, weil man es einfach nicht schafft, den Sprung zuverlässig zu wiederholen.
Auch das Leveldesign trägt zum allgemeinen Frust bei. Einige Level sind so gestaltet, dass man 4-5 mal quer durch den Raum hüpft, um Schalter zu drücken, was eine triviale aber zeitaufwendige Aufgabe darstellt und zum Schluss kommt ein sehr schwerer Part an dem man häufig verreckt. Und dann muss man ständig erst den einfachen, zeitaufwendigen Part wiederholen, nur um dann wieder am viel zu schweren Präzisionssprung zu scheitern.
Auch die Gegnerelemente im Spiel, also Raketen, verfolgende Killerscheiben, Todeslaser, Minen usw. sind anfangs gut integriert, in späteren Leveln aber riesige Frustquellen. Man ist in späteren Leveln einfach überfordert mit der schieren Anzahl and Feindelementen auf dem Bildschirm, die einem auch viel zu kleine Reaktionsfenster lassen ( wo wir dann wieder beim Thema Präzision wären).
Das solls zum Thema Gameplay sein. Die Musik im Spiel ist generische Elektromusik, gefällt manchen vieleicht, mir nicht. Kann man ja zum Glück leise/stumm stellen und die eigene hören. Die Grafik ist sauber und simpel. Man sieht alles was man braucht, keine ablenkenden Elemente. Man kann jedoch neue Farbmuster freispielen, die meisten waren mit aber zu grell und haben mir in den Augen geschmerzt. Wäre ja alles kein Problem, wenn das Spiel nicht automatisch beim Freischalten auf das neue Muster wechselt.
Fazit: Simple Grafik und Elektromusik, gepaart mit einem viel zu präzisionslastigen Plattformer, der keinen vernünftigen Spielfluss hinbekommt.
